abstract: <jats:p>Recent surveys of Oahu’s Waianae Mountains uncovered a small, previously undescribed species of <jats:italic>Auriculella</jats:italic> that is conchologically similar to the three members of the <jats:italic>A. perpusilla</jats:italic> group all of which are endemic to the Koolau Mountain Range. However, sequence data demonstrate that the <jats:italic>perpusilla</jats:italic> group is not monophyletic. Moreover, the new species is not closely related to <jats:italic>A. perpusilla</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>A. perversa</jats:italic>, the only extant members of the group, but instead is sister to <jats:italic>A. tenella</jats:italic>, a species from the high spired <jats:italic>A. castanea</jats:italic> group. A neotype is designated for <jats:italic>A. auricula</jats:italic>, the type species of <jats:italic>Auriculella</jats:italic>; all members of the conchologically similar <jats:italic>perpusilla</jats:italic> group are anatomically redescribed; and lectotypes designated for <jats:italic>A. minuta</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>A. perversa</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>A. tenella</jats:italic>. The new species is described and compared to the type of the genus, members of the <jats:italic>perpusilla</jats:italic> group, and the genetically similar species <jats:italic>A. tenella</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
title: Overlooked but not forgotten: the first new extant species of Hawaiian land snail described in 60 years, Auriculella gagneorum sp. nov. (Achatinellidae, Auriculellinae)
